page.title: 04The Bridgewater Canal.
page.content: The canal was built between 1759 & 1766 and opened up the hinterland, linking Manchester and Worsley to Runcorn and the Mersey.A flight of ten locks dropped the canal 90 feet at the Runcorn end.Flats,wide and narrow boats traded on the canal in raw and manufactured bulk materials. Today the flight of locks has gone and the canal ends at Waterloo Basin,it has long since lost its commercial value.Now it has found a new lease of life as a leisure facility used by pleasure craft both hired and privately owned as well as being popular with anglers fishing for carp, roach,perch and bream.It also provides a habitat for a wide variety of bird and animal life,the most common being mallard,coot and moorhen.
